SEC. 3. UNENFORCEABILITY OF AGREEMENTS TO ARBITRATE DISPUTES REGARDING EMPLOYMENT AND REEMPLOYMENT RIGHTS OF MEMBERS OF THE UNIFORMED SERVICES. Section 4328 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the enforcement of arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except when parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises or for valid collective bargaining agreements. Federal law determines the applicability of this section to arbitration clauses. The validity and enforceability of arbitration agreements between employers and employees under section 4328 of title 38, United States Code, are determined by Federal law. Courts, not arbitrators, decide on the validity of such agreements, regardless of how the challenge is presented. This section applies to all contracts between employers and employees, regardless of when they were established. Section 4328 of title 38, United States Code, addresses the unenforceability of agreements to arbitrate disputes. It applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. Additionally, enhanced remedies are provided for the enforcement of employment and reemployment rights of members of the uniformed services. Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include remedies for State or private employers who violate employment rights, allowing for compensation or damages. State or private employers who violate employment rights under this chapter may be liable for damages including wages, benefits, and compensation denied or lost by the affected person, as well as any actual monetary losses incurred. Additionally, interest on the damages and liquidated damages may be awarded as remedies. The court may award liquidated damages not exceeding 100 percent of the compensation or damages awarded, plus interest, if the employer proves good faith and reasonable grounds for the violation. The court may also require the employer to comply with the provisions of this chapter. In cases of violations of the chapter by employers with 25 or more employees, punitive damages may be required if the violation was done with malice or reckless indifference. A person initiating an action is entitled to a trial by jury. Federal executive agencies may face consequences if found in violation. The Board can order a Federal agency to comply with employment provisions and compensate a person for any denied wages or actual monetary losses due to violations. Interest on the compensation amount will also be included. The Board may award liquidated damages in addition to compensation for denied wages or losses, calculated with interest. Liquidated damages can be up to 100% of the compensation awarded, unless the agency proves good faith and reasonable grounds for the violation. This requirement is outlined in Chapter 137 of Title 10, United States Code, which specifies that each contract for property or services must inform the contractor of their potential obligations under Chapter 43 of Title 38. Section 8 amends Section 4302 of Title 38, United States Code, to clarify that provisions apply to both substantive and procedural rights. Section 9 calls for a study by the Comptroller General on the effectiveness of federal programs educating employers on obligations regarding employment and reemployment rights of uniformed services members. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of Federal programs educating employers about their obligations under chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code. This study will assess current practices, identify best practices for small businesses, and explore collaboration opportunities among agencies for employer education. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress by December 31, 2012, detailing findings and recommendations on employer education regarding reemployment obligations under chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code.
